comments.body: Should this be switched with test right below? This is not valid Python syntax while the one below is valid Python syntax, but not valid `eval` syntax.
I'll check but iirc it fails in the assign block with a left hand side that is a list with a length of 2
strange ... that should simply throw the usual syntax error and not do any parsing outside of Python

you are right `'d c = a + b'` raises a SyntaxError in fix_missing_locations....I think I meant the `a = b = c`, which ends up having multiple assignment nodes (which I raise a Syntax Error); though in theory in the future you could handle
can u change the test to make sure the multiple assignment fails? again not meaning to be a troll....just want to make sure the correct error is checked

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +1162,1166 @@
        # multiple assignees
        self.assertRaises(SyntaxError, df.eval, 'd c = a + b')

        # invalid assignees

comments.body: @cpcloud did you mean something additional besides this?
oh nope! sorry didn't see that :+1:

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +1203,1207 @@        df = orig_df.copy()
        df.eval('c = a + b')
        self.assertRaises(SyntaxError, df.eval, 'c = a = b')

        # explicit targets

comments.body: I merged the fix for #10952. if you'd add this test, would be great. ping when green.

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +1518,1522 @@        self.check_result_type(np.float32, np.float32)
        self.check_result_type(np.float64, np.float64)
        # Did not test complex64 because DataFrame is converting it to
        # complex128. Due to https://github.com/pydata/pandas/issues/10952
        self.check_result_type(np.complex128, np.complex128)
